title: General Knowledge Quiz X (50 Questions)
description: Challenging but fair across space, ideas, language, inventions, and physical geography. No sports content.

items.q: Which planet has a day (rotation) longer than its year (revolution)?
items.a: Venus - rotates very slowly and retrograde; a Venusian day exceeds a Venusian year

items.q: What is the term for the point in an orbit farthest from the Sun?
items.a: Aphelion - counterpart is perihelion (closest)

items.q: Which NASA mission first landed humans on the Moon?
items.a: Apollo 11 - Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed July 20, 1969

items.q: What is the largest moon of Saturn?
items.a: Titan - thick nitrogen atmosphere and hydrocarbon lakes

items.q: Which type of star ends its life as a neutron star or black hole after a supernova?
items.a: Massive star - core‑collapse supernova can leave compact remnants

items.q: What structure is the flat, disk‑like region of icy bodies beyond Neptune?
items.a: The Kuiper Belt - source of many short‑period comets

items.q: What is the name for the apparent path of the Sun across the sky among the constellations?
items.a: The ecliptic - plane of Earth’s orbit projected on the celestial sphere

items.q: Which telescope succeeded Hubble with infrared capabilities launched in 2021?
items.a: James Webb Space Telescope - operates at L2 to observe the early universe

items.q: What is the term for a planet outside our solar system?
items.a: Exoplanet - thousands detected via transits and radial velocity

items.q: Which dwarf planet was reclassified from planetary status in 2006?
items.a: Pluto - redefined by the IAU’s criteria for planet classification

items.q: Which ancient Greek philosopher taught Alexander the Great?
items.a: Aristotle - student of Plato and tutor to the Macedonian prince

items.q: What does ‘cogito, ergo sum’ translate to in English?
items.a: “I think, therefore I am.” - foundational claim by René Descartes

items.q: Which branch of philosophy concerns right and wrong action?
items.a: Ethics - includes theories like deontology and consequentialism

items.q: Who wrote the 18th‑century work Critique of Pure Reason?
items.a: Immanuel Kant - a central text in modern epistemology and metaphysics

items.q: Which movement asserts that existence precedes essence?
items.a: Existentialism - associated with Sartre, de Beauvoir, and others

items.q: What is the ‘allegory of the cave’ meant to illustrate?
items.a: Plato’s theory of forms and enlightenment - prisoners mistake shadows for reality

items.q: Which philosopher is known for the ‘categorical imperative’?
items.a: Immanuel Kant - universal moral law derived from reason

items.q: Which 19th‑century thinker wrote Thus Spoke Zarathustra?
items.a: Friedrich Nietzsche - work introducing the Übermensch and eternal recurrence

items.q: What is the study of valid reasoning and inference called?
items.a: Logic - includes propositional and predicate calculus

items.q: Which Chinese text emphasizes harmony with the Dao and non‑action (wu wei)?
items.a: Tao Te Ching - foundational Daoist work attributed to Laozi

items.q: What is the term for a word that sounds like what it describes (e.g., buzz)?
items.a: Onomatopoeia - words imitating natural sounds

items.q: Which language family includes Hindi, Persian, and English?
items.a: Indo‑European - widespread family across Europe and South Asia

items.q: What is the process of forming a new word by blending parts of two words (e.g., brunch)?
items.a: Portmanteau - coined by Lewis Carroll, combining sound and meaning

items.q: Which writing system uses characters that each represent a syllable?
items.a: Syllabary - examples include Japanese kana

items.q: What is the study of the structure of words (roots, prefixes, suffixes) called?
items.a: Morphology - branch of linguistics analyzing word formation

items.q: Which punctuation mark is used to join independent but related clauses?
items.a: Semicolon - links closely related statements

items.q: What is the term for a word with the opposite meaning of another?
items.a: Antonym - opposite of a synonym

items.q: Which language is the primary liturgical language of the Roman Catholic Church historically?
items.a: Latin - used in the traditional Mass and ecclesiastical texts

items.q: What is a borrowed word that retains its original pronunciation or form called?
items.a: Loanword - adopted from another language with minimal changes

items.q: Which language revived as a spoken vernacular after centuries of liturgical use in the late 19th/early 20th century?
items.a: Modern Hebrew - standardized and popularized by Eliezer Ben‑Yehuda and others

items.q: Who invented movable‑type printing in Europe around 1450?
items.a: Johannes Gutenberg - printing press revolutionized book production

items.q: Which pair discovered the structure of DNA in 1953 using X‑ray data?
items.a: James Watson and Francis Crick - double helix model (with crucial work by Rosalind Franklin)

items.q: Who is credited with patenting the first practical telephone in 1876?
items.a: Alexander Graham Bell - US Patent 174,465 granted March 7, 1876

items.q: Which physicist formulated the laws of electromagnetism as a set of equations?
items.a: James Clerk Maxwell - unified electricity, magnetism, and light

items.q: Who developed the first successful polio vaccine in the 1950s?
items.a: Jonas Salk - inactivated (killed) virus vaccine introduced in 1955

items.q: Which engineer pioneered alternating‑current power systems in the 1880s–90s?
items.a: Nikola Tesla - AC induction motor and polyphase power distribution

items.q: Who created the programming language Fortran (1957) at IBM?
items.a: John Backus and team - early high‑level language for scientific computing

items.q: Which chemist discovered benzene’s ring structure after a famous daydream?
items.a: August Kekulé - proposed the cyclic structure in the 1860s

items.q: Who first successfully vaccinated against smallpox in 1796?
items.a: Edward Jenner - used cowpox material to confer immunity

items.q: Which astronomer cataloged nebulae and clusters, giving his name to Messier objects (M1, M31, etc.)?
items.a: Charles Messier - 18th‑century comet hunter who compiled a famous catalog

items.q: What is the highest mountain in Africa?
items.a: Mount Kilimanjaro - a stratovolcano in Tanzania, 5,895 m (19,341 ft)

items.q: Which river runs through the Grand Canyon?
items.a: The Colorado River - carved the canyon over millions of years

items.q: What mountain range forms a natural border between France and Spain?
items.a: The Pyrenees - stretching from the Bay of Biscay to the Mediterranean

items.q: Which river is the longest in South America?
items.a: The Amazon - by discharge the largest on Earth; by length among the longest

items.q: What is the highest peak in the Alps?
items.a: Mont Blanc - on the France–Italy border, 4,808 m (15,774 ft)

items.q: Which Asian river is known as the Huang He?
items.a: The Yellow River - cradle of Chinese civilization

items.q: What mountain range includes Mount Everest?
items.a: The Himalayas - vast range across South and East Asia

items.q: Which European river flows through Vienna, Bratislava, Budapest, and Belgrade?
items.a: The Danube - second‑longest river in Europe

items.q: What is the longest river in Europe?
items.a: The Volga - flowing through central Russia to the Caspian Sea

items.q: Which mountain range runs the length of Italy’s peninsula?
items.a: The Apennines - backbone of the Italian Peninsula
